items.title: Meta brings its anti-fraud facial recognition test to the UK after getting a thumbs up from regulators
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Meta expands its facial recognition test to the UK, which includes tools to prevent scams and help users recover compromised accounts.
- The company received approval from UK regulators after discussions about AI technology.
- In-app notifications will inform public figures in the UK about opting in to receive facial recognition-enabled protection against celebrity bait scams.
- Meta assures that any facial data generated will be deleted after one-time use for comparison.
- The rollout comes amidst a broader push for AI integration in Meta's services, while the company faces scrutiny over past facial recognition practices and lawsuits.

items.title: Defense tech startup Epirus raises $250M Series D to counter drone swarms
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Epirus raises an oversubscribed $250 million in Series D funding for anti-drone systems.
- Previous valuation was $1.35 billion during the Series C in 2022, with the current valuation confirmed to be over $1 billion.
- Major investors include 8VC, Washington Harbour Partners, Gaingels, and General Dynamics Land Systems.
- The funding will be used to expand internationally, improve supply chain resiliency, and establish a new simulation center in Oklahoma.
- Epirus' flagship product, Leonidas, uses high-powered electromagnetic pulses against drones and is a popular choice among U.S. military contracts, including a $66 million deal in 2023.

items.title: Quantexa nabs $175M at a $2.6B valuation to double down on data analytics for AI
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Quantexa raises $175 million in Series F funding, valuing the company at $2.6 billion.
- The funding helps expand data analytics for AI and improve anti-money laundering efforts.
- Major clients include Prudential, Vodafone, HSBC, and the U.K. government.
- License revenue up 40% year over year, now has 800 employees across 16 global offices.
- Plans to strengthen partnerships with Microsoft and Databricks to enhance AI capabilities.

items.title: Key ex-OpenAI researcher subpoenaed in AI copyright case
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Alec Radford, ex-OpenAI researcher, subpoenaed in a copyright case against OpenAI on February 25.
- Plaintiffs include authors Paul Tremblay, Sarah Silverman, and Michael Chabon, alleging copyright infringement related to OpenAI's AI models.
- OpenAI claims its use falls under fair use; previous claims against OpenAI were dismissed, but the direct infringement claim continues.

items.title: Judge rejects Musk’s attempt to block OpenAI’s for-profit transition
items.summary:
- A federal judge denied Elon Musk's motion for an injunction against OpenAI's transition to a for-profit company.
- U.S. District Court Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers noted Musk did not provide sufficient evidence for the injunction.
- The court is willing to hold an expedited trial based on claims that OpenAI's conversion is unlawful.
- Musk's lawsuit claims OpenAI abandoned its original nonprofit mission.
- Recently, Musk made a $97.4 billion unsolicited bid to purchase OpenAI, which was rejected by OpenAI's board.

items.title: Aspiration co-founder and board member defrauded investors of $145M, prosecutors say
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Aspiration co-founder Joseph Sanberg arrested for allegedly conspiring to defraud two funds of $145 million.
- Ibrahim AlHusseini, a former board member, pleaded guilty to wire fraud for falsifying documents to aid Sanberg.
- If convicted, both face up to 20 years in prison.
- The fintech startup had federal scrutiny for questionable financial practices prior to the criminal complaints.
- Sanberg secured loans using fraudulent tactics, including fake documents inflating assets.
- AlHusseini received $12.3 million from the scheme for guaranteeing repayment.
- The loans included a $55 million loan in 2020 and a $145 million loan in 2021. Sanberg defaulted on both loans, causing significant investor losses.

items.title: Amazon reportedly forms a new agentic AI group
items.summary:
[Amazon has formed a new group within AWS dedicated to creating AI agents.]
[AWS CEO Matt Garman stated that agentic AI could become a multi-billion dollar business for AWS.]
[Swami Sivasubramanian, a former AI and data team leader, will head the new group.]
[Recent developments showed Alexa+ with agentic capabilities like booking Ubers and navigating websites.]
[Amazon's AWS unit may develop enterprise agents to compete with Salesforce and Microsoft.]

items.title: X updates Communities with new filters, sorting options, and a way to see your own posts
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- X enhances Communities feature allowing users to engage in discussions akin to Reddit.
- New sorting options include filtering posts by Trending, New, or Popular, and a specific timeframe: day, week, month, year, or all-time.
- Update is currently available on the iOS app, with plans for future releases on web and Android.

items.title: African VC LoftyInc Capital launches third fund for seed and Series A, reaches $43M first close
items.summary:
- LoftyInc Capital reaches first close of its third fund, LoftyInc Alpha, at $43 million.
- Fund targets late-seed and Series A startups across Nigeria, Egypt, Kenya, and Francophone Africa.
- Includes a diverse group of limited partners, such as sovereign wealth funds and development finance institutions.
- Aims to bridge the funding gap from pre-seed to Series A in Africa's startup ecosystem.
- LoftyInc has a history of backing notable startups and aims to leverage operational expertise for its portfolio.

items.title: Andy Dunn’s new app Pie uses AI to help you make friends
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Andy Dunn, founder of Bonobos, launches a social app called Pie to help people make friends in real life.
- Pie raised $11.5 million in Series A funding and has over 130,000 monthly active users, available in San Francisco and Chicago.
- The app features an AI-powered quiz called Sparked Connections, grouping event attendees based on compatibility before social events.

items.title: Foundation Capital Raises $600M Fund, Focuses on Early Stage Investing
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Foundation Capital raised a $600 million eleventh flagship fund, 20% larger than its previous fund.
- The firm remains focused on seed stage investing, being the first institutional investor in over 70% of its portfolio companies.
- Notable past investments include early backing of Cerebras and Solana, with Cerebras currently valued at $4.25 billion.

items.title: Klarna CEO doubts that other companies will replace Salesforce with AI
items.author: Sebastian Siemiatkowski
items.summary:
- Klarna's CEO explains why the company switched from Salesforce to its own AI system over a year ago.
- He does not believe that other companies will follow Klarna's lead, suggesting that Salesforce is not at risk of going away.
- Klarna's in-house AI system, developed using OpenAI's ChatGPT, replaced 700 contract employees and saved approximately $40 million annually.
- Salesforce's CEO questioned Klarna's customer data management and compliance after the announcement.
- Siemiatkowski clarifies that Klarna consolidated data onto its own tech stack from various SaaS providers, not simply uploading data to OpenAI.

items.title: Amazon is reportedly developing its own AI ‘reasoning’ model
items.summary:
- Amazon is developing an AI model incorporating advanced reasoning capabilities.
- The model is expected to launch in June under Amazon’s Nova brand.
- Reasoning models provide step-by-step answers, improving reliability in math and science fields.
- Amazon intends to adopt a hybrid reasoning architecture for the model to deliver both quick answers and extended reasoning.
- The company aims to make the Nova model more price-efficient than competitors, which may be challenging.

items.title: Google still limits how Gemini answers political questions
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Google’s AI chatbot, Gemini, often states it “can’t help with responses on elections and political figures right now.”
- Competitors like OpenAI, Anthropic, and Meta AI engage more freely on political topics.
- Google initially announced restrictions in March 2024 before various elections and has not updated its stance since.
- Gemini has struggled to provide accurate political information, even failing to identify the current U.S. president and vice president at times.
- Critics claim Google is engaging in AI censorship by limiting responses to sensitive political discussions. 
- Other AI companies, including OpenAI, advocate for more open discourse on controversial topics.

items.title: Hackers launder most of Bybit’s stolen crypto worth $1.4B
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Hackers stole approximately $1.4 billion in cryptocurrency from Bybit, making it the largest crypto theft in history.
- The attack occurred on February 21, resulting in the loss of 401,346 Ethereum, which was later mostly converted to Bitcoin.
- North Korean government is suspected to be behind the hack, according to blockchain monitoring firms and the FBI.

items.title: OpenAI chairman Bret Taylor lays out the bull case for AI agents
items.summary:
- Bret Taylor, OpenAI board chair, shared insights on AI agents at Mobile World Congress in Barcelona.
- He highlighted the evolution of AI customer service agents, emphasizing their multilingual capabilities and instant response times.
- Taylor anticipates AI agents will become as significant for companies as websites or mobile apps within the next decade.
- Significant concerns include the necessity of implementing guard rails to prevent potential issues with AI accuracy and customer support.
- He stressed the importance of public-private partnerships to reskill the workforce affected by AI-driven job changes.
- Taylor reassured that OpenAI's mission to develop beneficial general AI will remain unchanged despite potential structural adjustments.

items.title: TechCrunch Sessions: AI speaker applications close March 7, submit yours today
items.summary:
- TechCrunch Sessions: AI event is on June 5, 2025, at Zellerbach Hall, UC Berkeley.  
- Applications for speakers close March 7, 2025, at midnight.  
- Speakers can lead 50-minute sessions including presentations and discussions for AI topics.  
- Selected speakers gain access to exclusive networking and promotional opportunities.  
- Topics can include startups, AI tools, infrastructure, and innovative ideas.

items.title: Google’s March Pixel Drop has AI-powered scam detection and live location sharing with friends
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Google announced March software updates for Pixel phones, including AI scam detection in calls and messages.
- The update also introduces live location sharing via the Find My Devices app and menstrual tracking on Pixel Watch 3.
- Beta testing concluded, favoring Gemini Nano for scam detection on Pixel 9 series in the U.S.
- Additional features: new screenshot app updates, external camera support for streaming, and image generation in Pixel Studio app.
- Expansion of satellite messaging support for Verizon and T-Mobile users, now including Canada and EMEA regions.
- New Gemini features include multimodal capabilities and support for over 45 languages for conversations.
- Android updates focus on scam detection and live tracking features for Android users, plus shopping insights in Chrome.

items.title: Automattic CEO Matt Mullenweg talks succession — ‘I don’t want to pass it to a committee’
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Matt Mullenweg, CEO of Automattic, faces calls to step down amid controversy with WP Engine.
- Plans to ensure succession without passing leadership to a committee; aims to find a suitable successor.
- Discussed the importance of retaining majority control for future leadership in a podcast.
- Emphasized the community's role and accountability in stewardship of WordPress.
- Recognized that Automattic’s efforts have introduced over 100 million users to WordPress software.

items.title: Cohere claims its new Aya Vision AI model is best-in-class
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Cohere released Aya Vision, a multimodal AI model claimed to be best-in-class for tasks like image captioning, Q&A, translation, and summarization in 23 languages.
- The model is available for free via WhatsApp and aims to bridge performance gaps in AI across languages.
- Aya Vision comes in two versions, 32B and 8B, with 32B outperforming larger models on certain benchmarks.
- Both models are accessible via Hugging Face under a Creative Commons license, but not for commercial use.
- Synthetic annotations were used in training to enhance efficiency and support for the research community.
- Cohere also introduced AyaVisionBench for evaluating vision-language tasks and addressing concerns in AI benchmarking.

items.title: Solar installer Sunnova races to raise cash as it issues ‘going concern’ warning
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Sunnova issued a 'going concern' warning due to cash shortages.
- The company’s stock is down approximately 68%, raising bankruptcy concerns.
- Sunnova plans to refinance debt, raise new debt, and cut expenses to avoid insolvency.
- The company reported a net loss of $447 million in 2024, down from previous losses, and its market cap has plummeted to around $63 million from a previous valuation of $4.5 billion.
- High interest rates and uncertainty about the Inflation Reduction Act are contributing to the instability of the solar industry.
- Sunrun, the largest U.S. installer, recently lowered cash generation guidance, indicating a challenging outlook for installations.
- Despite challenges, First Solar reportedly exceeded earnings expectations, highlighting some positive aspects in the industry.

items.title: Didi reportedly seeking funds for self-driving unit at $5B valuation
items.summary:
- Didi is seeking new funding for its autonomous vehicle unit, potentially valuing it at $5 billion.
- High investor interest in self-driving technology is noted, influenced by recent IPOs from WeRide and Pony AI.
- Didi's self-driving unit has raised $1.55 billion to date and is in discussions to raise more funds.
- Currently testing around 200 autonomous vehicles in major Chinese cities but has not yet launched commercial operations.
- Funds may aid in further development of AV technology and mass production of electric robotaxis, expected to begin in 2025.

items.title: On a quest to revive the woolly mammoth, Colossal Biosciences has created a woolly mouse
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
[Colossal Biosciences aims to resurrect the woolly mammoth by 2028](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/04/on-a-quest-to-revive-the-woolly-mammoth-colossal-biosciences-has-created-a-woolly-mouse/) and has made progress by creating a genetically engineered woolly mouse.
[Scientists used CRISPR](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/04/on-a-quest-to-revive-the-woolly-mammoth-colossal-biosciences-has-created-a-woolly-mouse/) to edit mouse embryos to exhibit mammoth-like fur traits, adapting them to survive in cold climates.
Approval from the [Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC)](https://olaw.nih.gov/resources/tutorial/iacuc.htm) is required before further experiments on these engineered mice can occur.

items.title: OpenAI launches $50M grant program to help fund academic research
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI announced a $50 million grant program to support AI-assisted research through a new consortium called NextGenAI.
- NextGenAI, comprising 15 academic partners including Harvard, Oxford, and MIT, aims to fuel AI discoveries and prepare future generations.
- The initiative comes amid challenges in U.S. AI research funding, particularly following staffing changes in the National Science Foundation under the Trump Administration.

items.title: Funding to women-founded startups declined 12% in 2024, but that wasn’t far behind the broader market
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Venture investment in startups run by women in Europe declined 12% in 2024, mirroring an 11% decline in overall venture investment.
- Women founded deep tech startups are raising more venture capital than their male counterparts, with 33% of capital raised by female entrepreneurs going into this sector.
- Female-founded businesses in Europe raised €5.76 billion in 2024, a decrease from €6.56 billion in 2023.
- Key areas of innovation driving female investment include synthetic biology, generative AI, and drug development.
- The U.K., France, and Germany lead in investment into female-founded companies, with Finland and Denmark having the highest proportion of venture capital allocated to these startups.

items.title: Polish space agency says it’s investigating a cyberattack
items.summary:
- Poland's space agency (POLSA) is investigating a cyberattack detected on March 2, 2025.
- POLSA disconnected its network from the internet immediately after the attack and its website remains offline.
- Poland's digital minister confirmed unauthorized access to POLSA's IT infrastructure and state cybersecurity services are working to identify the attackers.
- Poland has been identified as the most attacked EU country regarding cyberspace incidents, largely attributed to Russia.

items.title: Apple launches a new iPad Air with M3 chip
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Apple has launched new 11-inch and 13-inch iPad Air models with M3 chip, available for pre-order starting Tuesday and launching on March 12.
- Prices start at $599 for the 11-inch model and $799 for the 13-inch model, available in four colors and various storage configurations.
- The M3 chip offers significant performance improvements, being nearly 2x faster than the M1 and up to 3.5x than the A14 Bionic, with a new Magic Keyboard introduced as well.

items.title: Swap banks $40M to build tools for merchants to deal with tariffs and other cross-border trading nightmares
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Swap, a London startup, raised $40 million in Series B funding led by ICONIQ Growth to build logistics tools for e-commerce amid new tariffs.
- The expansion plan includes markets in Europe, the U.S., Australia, and Canada, aiming to enhance services for 500 brands already using its platform.
- The startup's founders, Sam Atkinson and Zach Bailet, leverage their experience in online commerce to address challenges in international shipping and tariffs.

items.title: Scrunch AI is helping companies stand out in AI search
items.author: Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- Scrunch AI helps companies optimize their online presence for AI search platforms.
- The platform audits and provides visibility into how AI crawlers interact with online content, updating every three days.
- Launched in fall 2023, Scrunch AI signed 25 customers, including Lenovo and Penn State University.
- The startup raised a $4 million seed round led by Mayfield to further develop its product.
- Competitors, like Profound, also address AI search optimization, indicating a growing market opportunity.

items.title: LlamaIndex launches a cloud service for building unstructured data agents
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- LlamaIndex launches LlamaCloud, a cloud service for creating AI agents that handle unstructured data.
- Founded in 2023 by Jerry Liu and Simon Suo, LlamaIndex offers tools for developers to create custom data agents.
- LlamaIndex has raised $19 million in Series A funding, totaling $27.5 million to date, aiming to expand its team and enhance product development.

items.title: Hotel management platform Mews books $75M round led by Tiger Global
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Mews, a SaaS platform for hotel management, has raised $75 million to support growing travel demand amidst economic uncertainty.
- Travel demand is forecasted to grow by 12% in 2025, reaching 1.75 billion arrivals, according to Oxford Economics.
- Mews reported significant growth, with 6,300 hotels now using its platform and revenue exceeding $200 million in 2024, driven by customer and service expansion.
- Tiger Global led this funding round, with prior contributors including Kinnevik, Battery Ventures, and Goldman Sachs Alternatives.
- The company plans to raise a larger round in a year or two, aiming to enhance its AI capabilities and service offerings for the hospitality sector.

items.title: Uber users in Austin are getting matched with Waymo robotaxis
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- Uber users in Austin can now choose between a Waymo robotaxi and a human driver as part of the newly launched “Waymo on Uber” service.
- The partnership between Uber and Waymo was officially launched on a Tuesday, just before the SXSW conference.
- As of now, users can opt for either service with identical pricing; additional settings can increase the chances of a robotaxi ride.
- The presence of Waymo robotaxis in Austin will be part of a growing fleet across Austin and Atlanta.
- Waymo is tasked with vehicle testing and rider support, while Uber oversees fleet management services after divesting its own autonomous vehicle unit in 2020.

items.title: Mistral urges telcos to get into the hyperscaler game
items.author: Natasha Lomas
items.summary:
- Mistral CEO Arthur Mensch spoke at Mobile World Congress, urging telecoms to invest in data centers and become hyperscalers.
- Mensch emphasized the need for Europe to build more data centers and decentralize cloud services currently dominated by major U.S. players.
- Mistral is investing in its own data center in France and has signed a distribution agreement with Free for their AI assistant, Le Chat.

items.title: Mach Industries, founded by 21-year-old Ethan Thornton, lands US Army contract, builds weapons factory
items.author: Ethan Thornton
items.summary:
- Mach Industries, founded by 21-year-old Ethan Thornton, secured a U.S. Army contract and plans to build its first factory in Huntington Beach, California.
- The factory, named Forge 1, will be 115,000 square feet and is part of a strategy to create decentralized factories for defense manufacturing.
- The company is working on a cruise missile called "Strategic Strike," which successfully passed initial flight tests in February 2025, under a developmental contract awarded in late 2024.
- Mach aims to produce 1,000 Vipers (a UAV) and 3,000 Glides (a bomb) each month at the new factory.
- The factory will also produce two main products: Glide, a bomb deployed from a high-altitude balloon, and Viper, known for its vertical takeoff capabilities.

items.title: Cino cracks bill-splitting at the moment of payment, raises seed round
items.summary:
- Cino, a European startup, raised €3.5m in Seed funding led by Balderton Capital.
- The app allows real-time bill-splitting directly at the point of payment from various accounts.
- Founded in Estonia, Cino plans to expand to the U.K. after operating in Europe since 2023.
- Users can create payment groups with adjustable split ratios and all payments are visible in the group feed.
- The app has shown 100% month-over-month growth in Finland and Italy, with customers averaging 17 uses a month.

items.title: Dutch startup QuantWare seeks to fast-track quantum computing
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- QuantWare, established in 2020, has raised €20 million ($19.27 million) in a Series A round.
- The startup focuses on scaling bottlenecks in quantum processing units (QPUs) through its VIO technology.
- Contralto-A, their first QPU for quantum error correction, is designed to be upgradeable and is significantly larger than existing solutions.

items.title: Moonwatt secures $8.3M to dial up solar’s staying power with sodium-ion storage
items.summary:
- Moonwatt is a clean tech startup from the Netherlands focused on sodium-ion battery storage for solar plants.
- The company secured €8 million ($8.3 million) in seed funding to develop its storage technology, aiming for pilot installations in 2024 and commercial deployments in 2027.
- Their system can potentially double the internal rate of return for solar power plants, increasing capacity factors up to 80%.

items.title: Trump Administration cuts may threaten AI research efforts
items.summary:
- The Trump Administration has terminated several National Science Foundation (NSF) employees with expertise in AI, jeopardizing key AI research funding.
- The Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships at NSF, which facilitated AI grants, is directly impacted by these layoffs, causing delays in project funding.
- AI experts, including Geoffrey Hinton, have condemned the cuts, particularly those pushed by Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency, leading to a public exchange on scientific integrity.

items.title: People are using Super Mario to benchmark AI now
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Researchers at Hao AI Lab benchmark AI performance using **Super Mario Bros.**, claiming it's tougher than Pokémon.
- **Claude 3.7** from Anthropic outperformed others, including **Claude 3.5**, **Gemini 1.5 Pro**, and **GPT-4o**.
- Game utilized an emulator and the **GamingAgent** framework for AI control over Mario, focusing on rapid decision-making for gameplay success.

items.title: General Catalyst loses three top investors as the firm expands beyond venture, contemplates IPO
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Three key investors resigned from General Catalyst, including Deep Nishar, Kyle Doherty, and Adam Valkin.
- The firm is shifting its strategy to act as an investment and transformation company after recent mergers, including with La Famiglia and Venture Highway.
- General Catalyst is reportedly considering an IPO as it evolves from a partnership model to include wealth management and other non-venture strategies.

items.title: You can now talk to Google Gemini from your iPhone’s lock screen
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Google Gemini users can access the AI chatbot from the iPhone lock screen with a new update.  
- The update allows the addition of a Gemini widget to call up Gemini Live, Google's voice feature, without unlocking the phone.  
- Apple’s Siri is reportedly facing delays until 2027, leading competitors like Google to enhance their AI offerings for iPhone users.  
- The Gemini app includes lock screen widgets for photography, setting reminders, and starting text chats.  
- Upcoming features will allow Android users to ask Gemini questions about video and onscreen content in real time, initially available for Google’s $20-a-month Gemini Advanced plan.

items.title: Singapore arrests alleged Nvidia chip smugglers
items.summary:
- Singaporean police arrested three men for allegedly smuggling Nvidia chips on March 3, 2025.
- The arrested individuals include two Singaporeans and one Chinese citizen, charged with fraud regarding server supplies.
- Investigations are ongoing to determine if the servers from Dell and Supermicro contained restricted Nvidia chips diverted from their intended destination in Malaysia.

items.title: Creator monetization platform Passes sued over alleged distribution of CSAM
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
• Passes, a monetization platform for creators, is facing a lawsuit for allegedly distributing Child Sexual Abuse Material (CSAM).
• Filed by creator Alice Rosenblum, the lawsuit claims Passes produced and sold explicit content of her when she was a minor.
• Besides Passes, individuals Alec Celestin and Lani Ginoza, and CEO Lucy Guo are also named in the lawsuit.
• The case raises questions about the responsibility of fan platforms in preventing illegal content distribution.
• Passes denies the allegations, asserting it operates a no-nudity platform and follows strict content moderation policies.
• The company uses Microsoft PhotoDNA to scan for CSAM and reports any findings to the NCMEC.
• Rosenblum's allegations include claims that Celestin pressured her to create explicit content before her 18th birthday.

items.title: MWC hears two starkly divided views of AI’s impact
items.author: Natasha Lomas
items.summary:
- MWC trade show features two contrasting perspectives on AI's impact.
- Ray Kurzweil presents a positive view, suggesting AI will enhance human life and healthcare, predicting a renewable energy revolution.
- Scott Galloway counters with a cautionary stance, warning of the negative effects of AI-driven algorithms on social behavior and political discourse.

items.title: The author of SB 1047 introduces a new AI bill in California
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- California state Senator Scott Wiener introduced a new AI bill, SB 53, aiming to protect AI whistleblowers and create a public computing cluster called CalCompute.
- SB 53 focuses on whistleblower protections and limits reprisals against employees disclosing critical AI risks, defining 'critical risk' with specific thresholds.
- The bill is a response to past controversies surrounding SB 1047, which was vetoed by Governor Newsom, and may face challenges in a changing legislative climate for AI safety in 2025.

items.title: Google Play update makes it easier to find Android apps with widgets
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Google announced updates to its Android widgets system to enhance app discoverability.
- New visual badges will indicate which apps offer widgets on their Play Store detail pages.
- A dedicated search filter for widgets will help users find relevant apps directly.
- A curated Editorial Page will showcase well-designed widgets, boosting app installs for developers.

items.title: Ramp has more than doubled its annualized revenue to $700 million
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Ramp crossed $700 million in annualized revenue as of January 2025.
- Previous milestones: $100 million by March 2022 and $300 million by August 2023.
- CEO Eric Glyman states Ramp accounts for 1-2% of the U.S. card market and is not yet profitable as it reinvests in R&D.
- The company raised $150 million in a Series D extension last April.
- AI utilization is helping reduce cash burn to less than $2 million per month, improving efficiency across teams.
- Ramp's valuation nearly doubled to $13 billion after a secondary share sale, up from $7.65 billion in April 2024.
- The startup employs over 1,000 people as of the end of 2024.

items.title: TechCrunch Sessions: AI speaker applications close March 7
items.summary:
- TechCrunch Sessions: AI will begin on June 5, 2025, at UC Berkeley's Zellerbach Hall.
- AI community members are invited to apply as speakers by March 7, 2025, before midnight.
- Selected speakers will lead a 50-minute session, covering pressing topics in AI, with audience engagement opportunities.
- TechCrunch audience will vote on submitted topics to determine which sessions will be featured.
- Speakers gain exposure through event listings, social media promotion, and networking opportunities.

items.title: TSMC pledges to spend $100B on US chip facilities
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- TSMC plans to invest at least $100 billion in U.S. chip manufacturing over the next four years.
- The announcement was made by President Trump during a press conference.
- Funding will go towards new facilities in Arizona to support AI chip production.
- This new investment brings TSMC's total U.S. investments to around $165 billion.
- Concerns persist about TSMC's monopoly and the U.S. dependency on Taiwanese chip manufacturing.
- TSMC is responding to increased U.S. demand for domestic semiconductor production amid geopolitical tensions.

items.title: Google releases SpeciesNet, an AI model designed to identify wildlife
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Google has open-sourced SpeciesNet, an AI model for identifying animal species from camera trap photos.
- SpeciesNet was trained on over 65 million images, including data from organizations like the Smithsonian and the Wildlife Conservation Society.
- The model can classify images into over 2,000 labels, assisting in biodiversity monitoring efforts.
- The release is part of Google's Wildlife Insights initiative, which aids researchers in analyzing wildlife population data.
- SpeciesNet is available on GitHub under an Apache 2.0 license, allowing broad commercial use.
